ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about various forms of visual narratives and how to write essays about them (analyzing a specific scene, putting a narrative in conversation with another text, and creating a researched argument).

This course helped me further develop analytical writing skills and deepened my understanding of how to craft persuasive literary research essays. I also learned about various visual narrative forms and the different ways images can interact with a text to influence a readers interpretation.

-how to better organize essays
-how to broaden my thinking and analysis of books and graphic novels
-comparing the commonalities and differences between authors' writing styles, image choices, word placement etc
-inquire and infer about the deeper meaning behind a text

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The different essays plus the creative group publication allows students to get feedback on many writing techniques, and it serves as a good introduction to writing. One weakness may be the breadth of the material covered since visual narratives can cover many other topics besides the books we discussed in class.

Strengths: The variety of material (graphic novels/memoires, film, essays, a video game, etc...) and subject matter (memory, feminism, history, environmentalism, exile, etc) covered over the semester kept things engaging, providing ample opportunity to explore and write about topics of interest. Also, between the instructor and peer reviews, I received a lot of feedback that helped me significantly improve my writing between first and final drafts. Weaknesses: If I had to point to some area of weakness, I would say class discussions were a bit slow-going at times. I wouldnt note this as a glaring fault though, and the instructor was pretty good about finding ways to get conversation to pick back up.
strengths-- very versatile in the reading material and assignments (images/ video games/ movies/ books); engaging

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course shifted well to a remote environment considering that it is a seminar. The main problem was that it felt harder to discuss ideas and outlines for essays and to work on the group publication. Discussions in class proceeded fine.
I really enjoyed how the intimacy of the class enabled more discussion and these discussions and thoughts could be furthered through breakout rooms.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it builds writing skills through a few different types of essays and the professor is good at posing thoughtful questions during discussions. The feedback on essays is also thorough.

Whether they consider writing a challenge or a strength, I would whole-heartedly recommend this course to another student. I saw an improvement in my writing by the end of the semester and I feel better prepared to write for other courses moving forward. Additionally, the works we engaged with over the semester were diverse in subject and form which made reading, writing, and discussions thought-provoking and enjoyable. The instructor was knowledgeable, accessible, and provided thorough feedback that was straightforward and immensely helpful to work with. If youre looking for a well-structured course and a supportive environment to improve your writing, Id say this is a good place to start.

This is a fabulous course for individuals who are interested in both literature and visual art; it manages to showcase the profound meanings that have been placed behind a rendition of a childhood favorite: graphic novels.
